text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.21.1, Appeals Statute Responsibility, General Statute Responsibility.

Revised IRM to add new subsection, IRM 8.21.1.1, Program Scope and Objectives, and its related sections containing internal control information required by IRM 1.11.2, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process. As a result, all other IRM sections were re-numbered.

) Throughout this document, the name of Appeals Policy has been changed to Policy, Planning, and Analysis due to the realignment and merging of Appeals Policy with Planning, Quality and Analysis. (
) Minor editorial changes and grammatical corrections were made throughout this IRM.

) Purpose: This IRM provides general statute protection guidance to all employees. The IRM deﬁnes case jurisdiction and outlines all employees’ and sponsibilities for statute protection when the jurisdiction of the case Safeguards for ensuring short statute cases are highly visible for protection purposes are also provided. (
) Audience: Appeals Employees. (
) Policy Owner: Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis is under the Director Case and Operations Support. (
) Program Owner: Appeals Policy is the program office responsible for technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals organization and is the Director of Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this (
) This IRM section provides general statute responsibility for all Appeals employees. It gives general instructions for employees to verify, update, monitor statute dates. IRM
, Statute of Limitations, Examination Process - Assessment Statute of Limitations Controls, provides guidance for statute protection for all IRS employees. (

) Appeals accomplishes its mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases, holding conferences, and negotiating settlements in a manner ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. IRC
). See also Pub
, Taxpayer Bill of Rights. (

) The Director, Case and Operations Support (C&OS) is the executive sible for designing, developing, delivering, and monitoring short and long administration policies, programs, strategies, and objectives for the organization. (

) The Director, Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis oversees the Appeals Policy function and is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees, establishing and maintaining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams. (
) The Policy Analyst shown on the Product Catalog page, as the originator, the assigned author of this IRM. (

) Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PPQ&A) provides trends and data analyses and detailed summary reports for Appeals. PPQ&A prepares the following report related to this program: TPP Exam Return Level Inventory Report. (

Statute Responsibility 8.21.1
Appeals Statute (

) The following IRMs provide Appeals employees with additional information statute responsibility, including veriﬁcation, monitoring, updating, and protec- tion: • IRM

, Statute of Limitations (
) This manual provides guidance to Appeals employees by deﬁning their sibility for verifying, updating, and monitoring statute dates. (
) The procedures presented, in this IRM, represent the minimum standard each employee is expected to follow when handling cases in Appeals. (

) All employees should be alert to possible statute situations or problems and take action, whenever possible, to prevent barred assessments. Note: When monitoring his/her monthly statute report and timesheet, the should be alert to situations such as cases that may have been closed are still on the employee’s timesheet. (
) Employees should always be aware of the statute dates on cases in their physical possession. They must continue to monitor the statute dates as as the case is in their possession. (

) Case jurisdiction does not merely mean having physical possession of a The employee charged with jurisdiction is accountable for verifying and toring the statute date on a case while it is in that employee’s jurisdiction. (

) Jurisdiction changes as a case travels through Appeals. When a case is ﬁrst received in Appeals, jurisdiction of the case is with Account and Processing Support (APS) when they acknowledge receipt of the case, using Form Document Transmittal. APS will use Form
to release jurisdiction for case movement out of APS. Jurisdiction of the case remains with APS until Appeals Team Manager (ATM) acknowledges receipt by signing Form
and promptly returning it to APS. Jurisdiction is with the ATM from the time Form
is received by APS until the assignment of the case to an Technical Employee (ATE). The ATM should timely assign the case to an Note: For a deﬁnition of technical employee, see IRM
, General Guide- lines for Appeals Technical Employees. (

) Once a case is assigned to a technical employee, the action code CR Received) will be input on the Case Activity Record (CAR) and jurisdiction shifts to that employee. Jurisdiction can transfer from one technical to another numerous times. The technical employee reﬂected on Appeals tralized Database System (ACDS) will be responsible for verifying and monitoring the statute while the case is assigned to him/her. 8.21 Appeals Statute Responsibility
The following IRMs provide Appeals employees with additional information for statute responsibility, including veriﬁcation, monitoring, updating, and protec-
This manual provides guidance to Appeals employees by deﬁning their respon- sibility for verifying, updating, and monitoring statute dates.
The procedures presented, in this IRM, represent the minimum standard that each employee is expected to follow when handling cases in Appeals.

Jurisdiction changes as a case travels through Appeals. When a case is ﬁrst received in Appeals, jurisdiction of the case is with Account and Processing Support (APS) when they acknowledge receipt of the case, using Form 3210, Document Transmittal. APS will use Form 3210 to release jurisdiction for all case movement out of APS. Jurisdiction of the case remains with APS until Appeals Team Manager (ATM) acknowledges receipt by signing Form 3210

) Once a case is assigned to a technical employee, the action code CR (Case Received) will be input on the Case Activity Record (CAR) and jurisdiction shifts to that employee. Jurisdiction can transfer from one technical employee to another numerous times. The technical employee reﬂected on Appeals tralized Database System (ACDS) will be responsible for verifying and monitoring the statute while the case is assigned to him/her.
Statute Responsibility 8.21.1

) Jurisdiction remains with the technical employee until the case is submitted the ATM. The technical employee will input the ACDS action code AC (submitted to Manager) when the case is submitted to their ATM for review approval. (

) When an ATM approves a case for closing via the ATM Closing Menu on ACDS, the ATM will input the ACAPDATE and the case is automatically entered on the Processing Employees Automated System (PEAS). shifts to APS when the case assignment is made on PEAS. When the returned to APS for closing, jurisdiction shifts back to APS and will remain APS until an assessment is made. (

) Jurisdiction can remain with one employee while another employee has physical possession of the case ﬁle. Although the employee with physical session is not responsible for verifying the statute date, that employee the movement of the case and therefore, must monitor the statute date the case is in his/her possession. Example:

) When issuing a statutory notice of deﬁciency, jurisdiction remains with the technical employee until the notice is issued. However since APS has physical possession of the case before the notice is issued, they must monitor the statute date to ensure the notice is issued Example:

) When sending a case to the Tax Computation Specialist (TCS) for tax computation, jurisdiction remains with the technical employee. However since the TCS has physical possession of the case, they monitor the statute date to ensure the work is completed in a timely manner. (

) Any employee having jurisdiction of a case shares accountability for and monitoring the statute with his or her manager. Any employee having physical possession of a case ﬁle shares accountability for monitoring the statute with his or her manager. (
) All tax returns with assessment periods expiring within
days or less considered short statute cases. To ensure these returns are highly visible; a. Place case ﬁle in a plain red folder. Complete and attach the ﬁllable, electronic Form
-A, Statute Expiration Case Notice, to the front the red folder. b. Attach a pink expedite tag to the folder for high priority processing. (

) When necessary, employees need to take additional actions to protect the sessment period on these cases. It may be necessary to hand-carry the from one location to another. If the ﬁle is being sent to a location outside of local office, use express mail or fax.

) Jurisdiction remains with the technical employee until the case is the ATM. The technical employee will input the ACDS action code AC (submitted to Manager) when the case is submitted to their ATM for approval. (

) When an ATM approves a case for closing via the ATM Closing Menu on ACDS, the ATM will input the ACAPDATE and the case is automatically entered on the Processing Employees Automated System (PEAS). shifts to APS when the case assignment is made on PEAS. When the returned to APS for closing, jurisdiction shifts back to APS and will APS until an assessment is made. (

) Jurisdiction can remain with one employee while another employee has physical possession of the case ﬁle. Although the employee with session is not responsible for verifying the statute date, that employee the movement of the case and therefore, must monitor the statute date the case is in his/her possession.

1) When issuing a statutory notice of deﬁciency, jurisdiction remains with the technical employee until the notice is issued. However since APS has physical possession of the case before the notice is issued, they must monitor the statute date to ensure the notice is issued

) When sending a case to the Tax Computation Specialist (TCS) for a tax computation, jurisdiction remains with the technical employee. However since the TCS has physical possession of the case, they monitor the statute date to ensure the work is completed in a timely manner. (

) Any employee having jurisdiction of a case shares accountability for verifying and monitoring the statute with his or her manager. Any employee having physical possession of a case ﬁle shares accountability for monitoring the statute with his or her manager. (
) All tax returns with assessment periods expiring within
days or less are considered short statute cases. To ensure these returns are highly visible; a. Place case ﬁle in a plain red folder. Complete and attach the ﬁllable, electronic Form
-A, Statute Expiration Case Notice, to the front of the red folder. b. Attach a pink expedite tag to the folder for high priority processing. (

) When necessary, employees need to take additional actions to protect the sessment period on these cases. It may be necessary to hand-carry the ﬁle from one location to another. If the ﬁle is being sent to a location outside of local office, use express mail or fax.

) When sending a case to the Tax Computation Specialist (TCS) for a tax computation, jurisdiction remains with the technical employee. However since the TCS has physical possession of the case, they must monitor the statute date to ensure the work is completed in a timely manner.
All tax returns with assessment periods expiring within 180 days or less are considered short statute cases. To ensure these returns are highly visible;
